message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on translation to help answer this question. The radiolabeled amino acids that do not bind to the ribosomal aminoacyl-site can be excised by the N-terminal peptidase. Only one of the options, 5'-CAU-3', codes for the amino acid methionine, which is typically found at the N-terminus of most eukaryotic proteins and is likely the target of the N-terminal peptidase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics and molecular biology for help. The question is asking about the anticodon sequence of the transfer RNA charged by the amino acid targeted by N-terminal peptidase. The radiolabeled amino acids that do not bind to the aminoacyl-site of the ribosome are the ones that can be excised by N-terminal peptidase, indicating that these amino acids are at the N-terminal position of a newly synthesized peptide. The only option with a start codon and a methionine (which is frequently the first amino acid in eukaryotic proteins) is (B) 5'-CAU-3', so this would be the charged transfer RNA used for N-terminal peptidase activity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biology for help. The question is asking about the anticodon sequence of the tRNA charged by the amino acid target of the N-terminal peptidase. The only option that corresponds to an amino acid with a sulfur-containing side chain is methionine, which has the anticodon sequence 5'-CAU-3'.

We refer to Biology articles on transfer RNAs and ribosomes for help. The question is asking for the anticodon sequence of the tRNA that is charged with the amino acid targeted by the N-terminal peptidase. The key to answering the question lies in the fact that the radiolabeled amino acids only bind to the peptidyl and exit sites of the ribosome, indicating that they have already been added to the growing peptide chain. Therefore, the tRNA charged with the amino acid targeted by the peptidase must be in the P-site, which means that it must have an anticodon sequence that is complementary to the codon in the A-site. The only answer choice that corresponds to a codon in the A-site is (B) 5'-CAU-3', which codes for the amino acid histidine. Therefore, the tRNA charged with histidine must have the anticodon 5'-AUG-3'.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics for help. The anticodon sequence of a transfer RNA determines which amino acid it is charged with during translation. Among the options, only CAU codes for histidine, which is the amino acid target of N-terminal peptidase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics and molecular biology for help. The question revolves around understanding the transfer RNA charged by the amino acid target of the N-terminal peptidase. The N-terminal peptidase cleaves proteins at the N-terminal end, which is usually the first methionine amino acid. Methionine is coded by AUG codon, which pairs with UAC anticodon on the initiator tRNA. Therefore, we can eliminate answer choices A, C, and D. The remaining option is B, which codes for histidine, another amino acid commonly found at the N-terminal end of proteins. The anticodon for histidine is CAU. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

We refer to Biology articles on the structure of transfer RNA (tRNA) for help. The anticodon sequence of tRNA charged by the amino acid target of the N-terminal peptidase will be complementary to the codon sequence in the mRNA at the ribosomal aminoacyl site, which is the second codon of the mRNA. Among the options, only (B) 5'-CAU-3' can pair with the mRNA codon 5'-AUG-3'.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on molecular biology for help. This question requires knowledge of the genetic code and how tRNAs match specific codons. From the options given, only option B (5'-CAU-3') codes for the amino acid methionine, which is the first amino acid in most eukaryotic proteins. The N-terminal peptidase cleaves the peptide bond between this methionine and the next amino acid, so it makes sense that the tRNA charged with methionine would not bind to the ribosomal aminoacyl site.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on molecular biology for help. The question involves understanding the anticodon sequence of a transfer RNA charged by the amino acid target of the N-terminal peptidase. The radiolabeled amino acids that can be excised by the N-terminal peptidase are the ones that do not bind to the ribosomal aminoacyl-site, indicating that they must only bind to the peptidyl and exit sites. This suggests that they are not being incorporated into a growing polypeptide chain, but rather are being released by the peptidase from the N-terminal end of a completed polypeptide. The only option among the choices that corresponds to a methionine amino acid, which is typically present at the N-terminus of a polypeptide chain, is (B) 5'-CAU-3', which pairs with the codon AUG.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on genetics for help. Sulfur-containing amino acids include cysteine and methionine, and the codon for methionine is AUG. The only option with AUG as the middle base is (B) 5'-CAU-3', which is the anticodon for the tRNA charged with methionine. Therefore, (B) is the correct answer.
